introduction.p: In Chapter 1, we considered models described by linear functions. In this chapter, we begin our study of nonlinear models.

subsection.title: Solving Nonlinear Equations
subsection.p: When studying nonlinear models, we will need to solve nonlinear equations. For example, in we used a graph to solve the quadratic equation 18x - x^2 = 80
Here is another example. The figure shows a table and a graph for the function y = 2x^2 - 5.

You can see that there are two points on the graph for each y-value greater than -5. For example, the two points with y-coordinate 7 are shown. To solve the equation 2x^2 - 5 = 7 we need only find the x-coordinates of these points. From the graph, the solutions appear to be about 2.5 and -2.5.

How can we solve this equation algebraically? The opposite operation for squaring a number is taking a square root. So we can undo the operation of squaring by extracting square roots. We first solve for x^2 to get \begin{aligned}[t] 2x^2 \amp= 12 \\ x^2 \amp= 6\\ \end{aligned} and then take square roots to find x = \pm\sqrt{6}

warning.p: Don't forget that every positive number has two square roots. The symbol \blert{\pm} (read “plus or minus”) is a shorthand notation used to indicate both square roots of 6.

subsection.p: The exact solutions are thus \sqrt{6} and -\sqrt{6}. We can also find decimal approximations for the solutions using a calculator. Rounded to two decimal places, the approximate solutions are 2.45 and -2.45.

webwork.pg-code: $quadtrue = RadioButtons( ["A quadratic equation may include a linear or a constant term.", "The solutions of a quadratic equation are always of the form \(\pm k\) .", "Your calculator gives exact decimal values for square roots of integers.", "The coefficients of a quadratic equation are called parabolas."], 0, );

statement.p: Which statement is true?

solution.p: A quadratic equation may include a linear or a constant term.

subsection.p: In general, we can solve equations of the form ax^2 + c = 0 by isolating x^2 on one side of the equation and then taking the square root of each side. This method for solving equations is called extraction of rootsextraction of roots.

assemblage.title: Extraction of Roots
assemblage.p:
To solve the equation ax^2 + c = 0
Isolate x^2.
Take square roots of both sides. There are two solutions.

statement.p:
If a cat falls off a tree branch 20 feet above the ground, its height t seconds later is given by h = 20 - 16t^2.
What is the height of the cat 0.5 second later?
How long does the cat have to get in position to land on its feet before it reaches the ground?

li.p: In this question, we are given a value of t and asked to find the corresponding value of h. To do this, we evaluate the formula for t = 0.5. We substitute \alert{0.5} for t into the formula and simplify. \begin{aligned}[t] h \amp= 20 - 16(\alert{0.5})^2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Compute the power.}}\\ \amp = 20 - 16 (0.25) \amp\amp \blert{\text{Multiply; then subtract.}}\\ \amp = 20 - 4 = 16 \end{aligned} The cat is 16 feet above the ground after 0.5 second.

We would like to find the value of t when the height, h, is known. We substitute h = \alert{0} into the equation to obtain \alert{0} = 20 - 16t^2 To solve this equation, we use extraction of roots. First we isolate t^2 on one side of the equation. \begin{aligned}[t] 16t^2 \amp= 20 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide by 16.}}\\ t^2 \amp= \frac{20}{16}=1.25 \end{aligned} Then we take the square root of both sides of the equation to find t = \pm \sqrt{1.25} \approx \pm1.118

stack.p: Only the positive solution makes sense here, so the cat has approximately 1.12 seconds to get into position for landing.
A graph of the cat's height after t seconds is shown at left. The points corresponding to parts (a) and (b) are labeled.

statement.p: Which solutions are approximations?

note.p: In part (a) of we evaluated the expression 20 - 16t^2 to find a value for h, and in part (b) we solved the equation 0 = 20 - 16t^2 to find a value for t.

p.m: \blert{{\small\text{Take the square root of both sides.}}}\hphantom{000} x=\pm

li.p: Give exact answers above; then give approximations rounded to two decimal places.
Note: Enter a comma between solutions.

statement.p: Use graphs to explain why a linear equation can have only one solution, but a quadratic equation may have two solutions.

subsection.title: Solving Formulas
subsection.p: We can use extraction of roots to solve many formulas involving the square of the variable.

statement.p: The formula V = \dfrac{1}{3} \pi r^2h gives the volume of a cone in terms of its height and radius. Solve the formula for r in terms of V and h.
Find a formula for the radius of a circle in terms of its area.
statement.instruction: Note: use "sqrt(2)" to get \sqrt{2}, and use "pi" to get \pi.

hint.p: Start with the formula for the area of a circle: A =
Solve for r in terms of A.

subsection.title: More Extraction of Roots

statement.p: Solve the equation ~3(x - 2)^2 = 48

subsection.p: Here is a general strategy for solving equations by extraction of roots.

assemblage.title: Extraction of Roots
assemblage.p:
To solve the equation a(px+q)^2 +r=0
Isolate the squared expression, (px + q)^2.
Take the square root of each side of the equation. Remember that a positive number has two square roots.
Solve each equation. There are two solutions.

statement.p: Solve 2(5x + 3)^2 = 38 by extracting roots.

li.p: Give your answers as exact values, separating the solutions with a comma.
Note: Use "sqrt(2)" to get \sqrt{2}, and take care to use parentheses appropriately.
Use the "Preview My Answers" button to see if you have entered valid syntax.
Find approximations for the solutions to two decimal places, separating the solutions with a comma.

statement.p: Which of the following equations cannot be solved by extraction of roots?

subsection.title: Compound Interest and Inflation
subsection.p: Many savings institutions offer accounts on which the interest is compounded annually. At the end of each year, the interest earned is added to the principal, and the interest for the next year is computed on this larger sum of money.

assemblage.title: Compound Interest
assemblage.p: If interest is compounded annually for n years, the amount, A, of money in an account is given by A = P(1 + r)^n where P is the principal and r is the interest rate, expressed as a decimal fraction.

statement.p:
Carmella invests $3000 in an account that pays an interest rate, r, compounded annually.
Write an expression for the amount of money in Carmella’s account after two years.
What interest rate would be necessary for Carmella's account to grow to $3500 in two years?

ol.label: a
ol.li: We use the formula above with P = 3000 and n = 2. Carmella’s account balance will be A = 3000(1 + r)^2

We substitute 3500 for A in the equation. \alert{3500} = 3000(1 + r)^2 We can solve this equation in r by extraction of roots. First, we isolate the perfect square. \begin{aligned}[t] 3500 \amp = 3000(1 + r )^2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 3000.}} \\ 1.1\overline{6} \amp = (1 + r )^2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Take the square root of both sides.}} \\ \pm 1.0801 \amp\approx 1 + r \amp\amp \blert{\text{Subtract 1 from both sides.}}\\ r \amp\approx 0.0801 \text{ or } r \approx -2.0801 \end{aligned} Because the interest rate must be a positive number, we discard the negative solution. Carmella needs an account with interest rate r \approx 0.0801, or just over 8%, to achieve an account balance of $3500 in two years.

webwork.pg-code: $first = RadioButtons( ["Expand \((x+1)^2\)", "Get zero on one side", "Divide both sides by 2", "Take the square root of both sides"], 2, );

statement.p: What is the first step in solving the equation 2(x+1)^2=17?

subsection.p: The formula for compound interest also applies to the effects of inflation. For instance, if there is a steady inflation rate of 4% per year, in two years an item that now costs $100 will cost \begin{aligned}[t] A \amp= P(1 + r)^2\\ \amp = 100(1 + 0.04)^2 = \$108.16 \end{aligned}

statement.p: Two years ago, the average cost of dinner and a movie was $24. This year the average cost is $25.44. What was the rate of inflation over the past two years?
r\approx%

subsection.title: Other Nonlinear Equations
subsection.p: Because squaring and taking square roots are opposite operations, we can solve the equation \sqrt{x} = 8.2 by squaring both sides to get \begin{aligned}[t] (\sqrt{x})^2 \amp= 8.2^2 \\ x \amp = 67.24 \end{aligned} Similarly, we can solve x^3 = 258 by taking the cube root of both sides, because cubing and taking cube roots are opposite operations. Rounding to three places, we find \begin{aligned}[t] \sqrt[3]{x^3}\amp=258\\ x \amp \approx 6.366 \end{aligned}

webwork.pg-code: $sqneg = RadioButtons( ["Nothing; that is the right answer.", "He should have put parentheses around \(6^2\).", "He should have put parentheses around \(-6\).", "You cannot square a negative number on a calculator."], 2, );

statement.p: Delbert squared -6 by entering -6^2 into his calculator, and got -36. What went wrong?

solution.p: He should have put parentheses around -6.

subsection.p: The notion of undoing operations can help us solve a variety of simple nonlinear equations. The operation of taking a reciprocal is its own opposite, so we solve the equation \frac{1}{x} = 50 by taking the reciprocal of both sides to get x = \frac{1}{50}= 0.02

statement.p: Solve ~~\dfrac{3}{x - 2}= 4
What is the reciprocal of \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x}}?
Solve 2\sqrt{x + 4} = 6
What is the difference between a rational number and an irrational number? Give examples of each.

technology.title: Using the Intersect Feature
technology.p: We can use the intersect feature on a graphing calculator to solve equations.

statement.p: Use a graphing calculator to solve ~~\dfrac{3}{x -2}= 4

solution.p:
We would like to find the points on the graph of ~~y = \dfrac{3}{x -2}~~ that have y-coordinate equal to 4. We graph the two functions \begin{aligned}[t] Y_1 \amp = 3/(X - 2) \\ Y_2 \amp = 4 \end{aligned}
in the window \begin{aligned}[t] \text{Xmin} \amp = -9.4 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 9.4\\ \text{Ymin} \amp = -10 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 10 \end{aligned} The point where the two graphs intersect locates the solution of the equation. If we trace along the graph of Y_1, the closest we can get to the intersection point is (2.8, 3.75), as shown in figure (a). We get a better approximation using the intersect feature.

Use the arrow keys to position the Trace bug as close to the intersection point as you can. Then press 2nd TRACE to see the Calculate menu. Press 5 for intersect; then respond to each of the calculator's questions, First curve?, Second curve?, and Guess? by pressing ENTER. The calculator will then display the intersection point, x = 2.75, y = 4, as shown in figure (b). The solution of the original equation is x = 2.75.

statement.p: Use the intersect feature to solve the equation 2x^2 - 5 = 7. Round your answers to three decimal places. Separate solutions with a comma.
